content.description:
This line is a steep slab with a small rib between bolts 1 and 2. It is between

Drefach Lambda

and

Unknown 1

(aka

Black Bart

). The crux is the slippery, thin slab around bolts 1-3. Once on the small shelf mid-climb, join either of the routes mentioned above to get to the anchors that these three routes share.
content.protection:
4 bolts, merges with

Drefach Lambda

or

Black Bart  (aka Unknown  1)

for another 3-4 bolts to the anchors.
content.location: It is on the section of Atlantis Dome that is closest to the road, just above the big boulder that the trail hikes up to.

content.description:
Using the anchor of

Seventh Wave

, you can TR the steep slope directly above the anchors that harbor

Snark Hunt

,

Dam The Water Board

, and

No Bore a Bora

.
content.protection:
TR anchors from

Seventh Wave

.
content.location:
Begin directly above the anchors for

Dam The Water Board

and TR'd from

Seventh Wave

, and climb left of

Seventh Wave

and left of a black stained streak.

climbs.name: Two Dikes for Dinner (submitted as Missing The Dike)

content.description:
Missing the Dike (aka Two Dikes for Dinner) is located on Atlantis Slab. As you approach the slab, find an area that has several bolted lines ascending from a flat area near a trench in the rock. Scramble into the trench for the belay. Locate a left-angling line of old 1/4" bolts near a black dike (the first line of bolts directly right of a newer climb). Climb onto the slab from the trench and follow the line of bolts. The dike will become obvious and useful until it ends at the last 1/4" bolt where you have to use a rotten hold (the hold is about to break, use caution). Slab your way to a good two bolt anchor.

This is a typical South Platte climb with the usual manky 1/4" bolts. Well recommended, but please don't fall.
content.protection: Four bolts to the top. Three 1/4" bolts and one new 3/8" bolt near the crux.

content.description: This is not my route, but it's a good choose-your-own-slab adventure. I HOPE nobody bolts this, since it's a perfect TR with lots of options at many grades (as the friable holds come and go).
content.protection: TR.  Double anchors are straight over all the choices.
content.location:
This is the 5th route in the new book.  It starts wherever you want to begin right of

Mermaid

and ends anywhere you want to top out left of

Two Dikes for Dinner (submitted as Missing The Dike)

(aka Two Dikes for Dinner in the new book).

content.description:
This route is on Atlantis Slab, near the center, and just to the right of the block laying a couple feet away from the base of the wall.

Transformer climbs the line just to the right of "

Hot Lava aka Soliloquy

" to the same anchor. Climb up through the blocks and flakes and pull left to a bolt and up a thin crack. Straight up to a little ledge and up the semi-dirty, left-facing flake, traversing left to the anchors.

This is a decent route, worth doing once, but it is probably not a destination route.
content.protection: A couple draws for a good bolt (per rob bauer), and light rack of RPs to wide, hand-sized pieces.

content.description:
The first pitch has a bit of a contrived section nearing the top along the traverse. It looks like you can just walk across up there, so I kept it bolted in a way that you can stay down low and move across. It is a bit weird but fun through there.

The crux is on the second pitch moving out of the crack. Also, it has an odd and interesting move at the end of the traverse (this could possibly be a little harder than 5.6. ;-)

Below the anchors, you'll see a chopped bolt. I did that as it was one hell of a BAD "spinner" and also had been lead without it. It is not needed and not having it adds a little spice to the end.

--- Invalid image id: 108894427 ---
content.protection: Draws.
content.location: This is on the left side of formation when facing it.

content.description:
The crux may be the whole thing.

LOL!

Blue is "Tim's Variation". Red/orange is "Tim's Walkway".

Photo by BLITZO.
content.protection: There is a separate set of anchors up top for rapping in and TR'ing out.
content.location:
Start at the second pitch of

Tim's Walkway

.

climbs.name: This Bolt's For You
climbs.fa: John McMullen, Tim Hudgel, & Carl Rasmussen, 1986

content.description:
This route is on Atlantis Slab. It is located towards the right side of the crag, just as a steep, bushy, rocky hill meets the wall. The route is visually obvious by a crack system that starts about 20 feet above the ground and goes from RPs to hands.

It has an ironic name. The guidebook shows a bolt on the initial slab getting to the RP seam, but it [was] no longer there. The crux is getting established a couple moves into the RP seam, and getting there is definite crater potential.

Start from below and to the right, and work your way up and left on a steepening slab to the RP seam. Place several pretty good RPs, and keep working upwards. The climbing getting progressively easier and transitioning through the sizes. Rap from a 3 bolt anchor. In the past, you may have needed to bring some webbing to "freshen up" the anchor.

When I did this, I had to garden as I went as the crack was loaded with dirt and weeds. With some cleaning, this would be a really good route.
content.protection:
RPs to hands.

Per

Jay Eggleston

: there is a bolt on this now as it has been replaced. The anchor has been replaced too, so there is no reason to carry webbing to "freshen" it up.

content.description:
Start up a slab below some bushes on a large ledge.  Climb past two bolts, then negotiate the prickly bushes.  I traversed below them.  From the ledge, join with

Dam The Water Board

up to the anchor.

The crux comes before the first bolt, but there is a flake and a thin crack for gear.

Other than the bushes, I thought this is a pretty good route.
content.protection: 2-bolts, light rack.
content.location:
See the photo.  Snark Hunt is between

The Leper

and

Dam The Water Board

.  The route finishes at the

Dam The Water Board

anchor.  Rap from there (a 60m works).

content.description:
Follow the black streak under the left corner of the roof above. Make your way to the ledge left of the roof, work up the crack, and follow bolts that are left-arcing along a seam up to the anchors at the top of the wall.

There is an unknown route that can be toproped from the anchors of this climb.
content.protection: 7 bolts, standard rack.
content.location:
Begin at the black streaks below the roof several feet to the right of

The Natives are Restless

.

content.description:
I gave this route a name as has been done to the other unknowns found in the newest book. If you fall before clipping the second bolt, you will experience a groundfall. I thought the crux was above this second bolt, but the

Fluff Boys

terrain above is not easy either. This route is much like the others in the area, but it gives you something else to do if you have done the other nearby routes.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This route is between

Missing the Dike

and

Fluff Boys

. You clip the first bolt on

Missing the Dike

as you start. You then clip a second bolt before joining

Fluff Boys

and clipping its last three bolts. There is an anchor to use to get down at the top.

climbs.name: No Bore a Bora
climbs.fa: John McMullen, Marc Hirt, Tum Hudgel

content.description:
Start on the tiny seam with balancy moves, and gain the small ledge. The crux is probably the awkward bulge above the single bolt found on this route. Finish at the anchors of

Dam The Water Board

.
content.protection: 1 bolt with standard rack.
content.location:
No Bore a Bora starts to the right of

Dam The Water Board

and ends on the same anchors as

Dam The Water Board

as well.

content.description: There are 5 chopped bolts that up the steep face, then traverse left to the anchors of No Bore a Bora and Dam the Water Board. This route can be toproped from those anchors from the two climbs to the left.
content.protection: The are anchors at the top.
content.location:
This is to the right of

No Bore a Bora

and just left of

Seventh Wave

where the black smears on the rock begin.

content.description:
This is not my route, but it is another one for the database.

Bad name: how about Mermaid?

It is a long way to the 1st bolt on what is essentially a 2 bolt climb, but the crux is probably at the bottom, depending how close to the water streak you start. Climbing far right is easiest. It's friable everywhere.
content.protection: 3 bolts, including the directional on the wall. Move the belay 20' right to a 2 bolt anchor with chains. A 60m rope will work if you want to belay from the ground.
content.location:
This is now the 6th bolt line [route #4 (L->R) in the Haas guidebook] about 80'(?) right of

Black Bart

. Start on a wide, clean area between trees, just right of a water streak on the left third of the dome.

content.description:
This route is on the Atlantis Slab.  It is towards the right end of the slab where the rocky, bushy little hill meets the wall.  It starts just to the right of the bottomed out handcrack (Island Rhythm).

Begin a little uphill and to the right of Island Rhythm, pulling up onto the slab and climbing increasingly difficult slab.  Good TR to hone your technique on the slightly friable thin edges and delicate smears of this section of the Platte.
content.protection: TR from the anchors on "This Bolt's For You"

climbs.name: Island Rhythm
climbs.fa: John McMullen, Tim Hudgel, Carl Rasmus sen 1986

content.description:
This route is located on the Atlantis Slab.  It is toward the right side of the slab, just as a rocky, bushy little hill meets the slab.  It is visually apparent by a flaring, bottoming crack that starts from the ground and peters out after about 30 feet into a smooth slab.

Jam up the awkward, bottoming crack until it fades into a smooth, steep slab.  Straight up on thin, friable flakes and smearing, past several old bolt holes to the anchors.  Fun climbing that is best TR'd, though it could maybe be lead with the "removable bolts" that are kind of hard to find these days.
content.protection:
Best done as a TR. It originally had some bolts on the slab above the crack, but they are gone.

Per

Jay Eggleston

: the 5 bolts have been replaced.

content.description:
This route is on Atlantis Slab, pretty much near the center.  There is a large block on the ground at the base that forms sort of a trough.  This route begins slightly to the right.  From below, it is apparent by a system of thin block/flakes that make up the slab in this section.

Climb straight up, following the path of least resistance.  The rock sounds a bit hollow through here when you pound on it.  Go straight up over a big, hatchet-faced flake of sorts onto a ledge.  Fire straight up over several more ledges and slab climbing past a bolt and onward to the anchor.  Rappel from a 2 or 3 bolt anchor.

It is a decent route, probably one to do once, but not a destination.
content.protection: A light Platte rack, stoppers, and a set of pieces to wide hands.

content.description:
On Atlantis Slab, follow the main trail to the left-center side of the slab. This route starts at the upper right end of the trench described for Missing the Dike. Look for a left angling seam/ramp and 4 newish bolts next to 1/4" studs. Step up, and follow the seam/ramp for about 20 feet to the first bolt (couple of so-so stoppers possible halfway). Head up to bolt #2 then left past two more bolts and the crux to the ledge and anchors (shared with Missing the Dike). Watch out for loose rock on the ledge.

The guidebooks give this a R rating past the last bolt, but the fall looks clean, relatively short and not too bad, since it's on a 3/8" bolt.

2-1/2 stars.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 4-6 runners, plus something for the top; a few mid-range stoppers.

climbs.name: Drefach Lambda
climbs.fa: TR, Locker and Matt Clark, first lead - Matt Clark and Locker

content.description:
This is an OK route.

Per

Jay Eggleston

: the crux seems to be at the steep section by the 4th bolt.
content.protection: 5 bolts.
content.location: This is on the left side of formation. Be careful of the poison ivy at the base of the climb!

climbs.name: Dam The Water Board
climbs.fa: Ed Hackstaff, MarionDurr and Brett Bristol, 1987

content.description:
Dam The Water Board climbs a slab to a large ledge, then follows flakes and crack to an anchor. The only bolt is approximately 20 feet off the ground, and if you come off before the ledge, you may be grounding. Above the ledge protects fairly well.

Snark Hunt

to the left offers a safer lead, but it is harder.

Mr. Hubbel shows a right variation. It did not seem any harder this way, but you are definitely grounding if you come off going this way.
content.protection: 1-bolt & light rack.
content.location:
See the photo. Dam The Water Board lies between

Snark Hunt

on the left and

No Bore A Bora

on the right. To descend, rap from anchor (60m works). If toproping, you will have to rap from trees at the top to the Dam The Water Board anchor.

content.description:
This isn't my route, but let's post it to the database (I hate "unknowns," so I'm arbitrarily calling it Black Bart).

This whole dome is a bit friable, and IMHO, this was at least 10d. I thought it good. Let's see what you think?
content.protection: 6 good bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is now the 5th route, L->R, about 15' right of

Unsupervised Bolting

. It angles up left from just left of a big pine, in the wide, black streak.

content.description:
This route climbs the left end of the formation along the skyline. The start has 3 choices: a finger crack and staying left of the bolts all the way up is about 5.6; the center slab, perhaps 8; and right of the bolts, maybe 9? After the 7th bolt, the rock flattens out considerably, and the bolts space out along a blunt arete.

If you TR this, bring a 70m rope. It is an easy walk up, but I didn't install separate anchors, and the rope will want to fall off toward

Tim's Walkway

... knot your end and maybe leave the top few draws in.

What's with the name? According to early DC comics, Aquaman was the king of Atlantis.
content.protection:
9 bolts to the anchor bolts on

Tim's Variation

, which have no rings or chains.

If you want to nut the finger crack, it takes wires and/or up to a #0.4 Camalot.
content.location:
On the left end of the formation, there is a huge in-place flake which forms a shallowing, right-facing corner next to a beautiful face. Start from the spacious "feldspar mine" below some choss. (The little crow's nest I originally used eroded). This is about 40' left of

Tim's Walkway

and uphill a bit.

The walkoff takes 1 minute or you could rap off

Tim's Walkway

.

content.description:
This climb starts about 60 feet off the deck, above the 5.11

Island Rhythm

(?). Either lead another route up to it, or rap in from above and climb back out.
content.protection: Two or three draws, two anchors. Obviously, be careful when rapping in. (You can either TR it at this point, or clip to the anchors, pull the rope, and lead back up).
content.location:
The route is located above the 5.11

Island Rhythm

.
